Translation of 楚竹書・曹沫之陳(en) into English.

p.seg: Duke Zhuang of Lu was going to make a big bell,
the mold had already been completed.
Cao Mo entered the court and was received,
and said:
"In the past when the house of Zhou enfeoffed Lu,
its territory consisted of seven hundred li from east to west
and five hundred from south to north,
there was no mountain or marsh
without people behaving as dutiful subjects (=there was order even in marginal areas).
Now the state has gotten smaller
while the bells have gotten larger,
shouldn't the lord make plans about it?
In the past when Yao provided food for Shun,
he would eat in an earthenware gui vessel,
drink in an earthenware xing vessel,
and he stabilized and possessed all under Heaven.
Is this not a case of being poor in beauty
but rich in virtue?
In the past the house of Zhou [...]
[...] territory will necessarily be won,
(so) one can make the state well ordered,
this is preserved in the Zhou records.
Duke Zhuang said:
“[...] since among the rulers of today (these principles) are already (well) known,
who could (actually) attract people (at the expenses of their neighbours)?”
Cao Mo said:
“Your majesty should not be grieved (perplexed).
I heard it said:
"If the lord of the neighboring country is enlightened,
then one cannot but reform the government
and be good to the people,
otherwise one fears them to flee.
If the lord of the neighboring country is unprincipled,
then one also cannot but reform the government
and be good to the people,
otherwise there will be no way to get them.”
Duke Zhuang said:
“In the past Shi Bo told me:
‘for the ruler to obtain it or to lose it (=success),
is the will of Heaven.’
Now, this is different from your words.
Cao Mo said:
“[...] there is nothing by which it differs from my words,
your majesty has not gone to the bottom of it.”
I heard it said:
“If the ruler is considered worthy and loses it,
it is the will of Heaven;
if he is considered unprincipled
and dies having reached the (natural) end of his life,
it is also the will of Heaven.”
Otherwise, if a ruler is considered worthy,
how could it be that he does not get it?
If he is considered unprincipled,
how could it be that he does not lose it?”
Duke Zhuang said:
“How late
have I heard these words (how slow have I been in realizing their truth)!.”
Then he ordered to destroy the bell’s mold
and attended to the government of the state.
He did not sleep during the day,
did not drink wine,
did not listen to music,
in his residence he did not use refined ornaments,
in his eating he did not eat two dishes (?)
[...] he loved all his myriad subjects
and did not have selfish concerns.
The following year he (again) asked Cao Mo:
“I want to make war with Qi,
could I ask you about the battle array
and the defense of border walled towns?”
Cao Mo answered:
“I have heard:
there are secure plans,
but there are no secure walled towns.”
There are conquering policies,
but there are no conquering battle arrays.
The battle arrays of the three dynasties are all extant,
some win with them, some lose with them.
moreover, I have heard that:
“When a small state is situated between big states,
in the areas of contact [=the main thoroughfares connecting] with the enemy state
one cannot be first in making enemy acts (=start the hostilities),
nor should you act first in the (marginal) areas at the border but (rather) you should (first) obtain [strongholds?] there,
thereby protecting the borders.
you should not begrudge goods and resources and (beautiful) young ladies,
to provide for his favorites,
thereby being protected inside;
The inner and outer city walls must be repaired,
armor must be kept in good order and weapons sharpened,
there must be a fighting spirit for defense,
in this way one acts as a leader.
Moreover I have heard this:
“If one is not in harmony with the state,
one cannot set out (military) preparations.
f one is not in harmony (=well prepared) with the military preparations,
one cannot set out with the battle array.
If one is not in harmony (=well prepared) with the battle array,
one cannot start war.
Therefore the battle array is the last of the three teachings.
As you will certainly not stop,
then why not proceeding from its root (=starting from the beginning)?
Duke Zhuang said:
“How should one proceed to achieve harmony in the state?”
Cao Mo answered:
“Do not get the people’s time (=do not interfere with their agricultural work),
do not seize the people’s assets,
feed them arranged (according) to their contributions,
punish and fine the guilty
and reward and enfeoff the virtuous.
Duke Zhuang said:
‘How should one proceed to achieve harmony in the (military) preparations?”
Cao Mo said:
“When the army sets out,
the ruler should personally lead it;
there must be two generals.
Every general should have many favorite chief officials,
every favorite chief official should have many masters of the great office,
the duke's grandsons and the duke’s sons.
All the officers in command,
[...] no complications in the timely deployment (of the army);
in this way one achieves harmony in military preparations.
Duke Zhuang asked again:
‘How should one proceed to achieve harmony in the battle’s array?”
He answered
Amongst the war carts there must be room for a unit of five,
within a unit of five there must be space for the weapons,
the ones in high position and with good salary,
let them be in the front lines;
after the first three lines,
from behind will be seen the soldiers with the short weapons;
between the units of ten and five soldiers there should be the duke's grandsons and the duke’s sons,
this is what we call the military rule.
Five men constitute a unit of five,
and when one man has merit,
the other four all get a reward,
this is the way to adjudicate (rewards).
Do not emphasize capture
but emphasize compliance to orders,
acting in this way the troops will not retreat.
The commanders of the carts should be on the cart,
the commanders of the foot soldiers should proceed on foot,
in this way they will be equal towards death.
There is a cautionary saying:
“If (your troops) run around wildly
you will certainly be in chaos;
if they do not run around wildly,
they will probably come together strongly
and quietly unite.”
Therefore the general does not let the troops run around wildly,
if they run around wildly they will not come into the ranks.
In war there is a manifest rule:
do not wage war by conquest (=do not rely on aggressive war to win).
Duke Zhuang said:
“what do you mean by not waging war to win?”
He answered:
“If other’s weapons are not tempered,
my weapons must be tempered.
If other’s armors are not solid,
my armor must be solid.
If others employ officials,
I will employ great officials.
If others employ great officials,
I will employ generals,
If others employ generals
I, the ruler (or: my ruler?) will personally advance.
This is the manifest rule of war.”
The duke said:
“since I have already completed my instruction (about the above preparatory issues),
is there a crucial time to send out an army?”
He answered:
“There is.
I have heard that
when an army sets out,
if the general is of low status,
if the elders do not recommend him,
if he is controlled by his state (=has no autonomy of command),
this is the crucial time to send out the army.”
Duke Zhuang asked again:
“If the (enemy) army is dispersed and tied up (?),
is there a crucial time?”
He answered:
“There is.
I have heard this:
when the army has not yet completed the battle array,
not yet (finished) the preparations (of the camp),
is going up a slope or wading a dike,
this is the crucial time of dispersion and entaglement.”
Duke Zhuang asked again:
“Is there a crucial time for fighting?”
He answered:
“There is.
When his leaving is not quick
when his approaching is not close,
and his timing for initiating (battle) is not prompt,
this is the crucial time for fighting.
Therefore being hesitant in the battle’s array one will be defeated,
being hesitant in fighting one will die.”
Duke Zhuang asked again:
“Is there a crucial time after the fighting has started?”
He answered:
“There is.
When the enemy’s rewards are few and not fair,
his punishments heavy and undiscerning,
when the bodies of the dead are not collected,
when the wounded are not asked about (=taken care of),
the fighting has already started
and yet there is a negligent spirit,
this is a crucial time after the fighting has started.”
Duke Zhuang asked again:
“Is there a way to fight again after defeat?”
He answered:
“There is.
When the army is defeated,
one should collect the bodies of the dead
and ask about the wounded;
being good to the dead
is done for the living.
The ruler then should recognize his faults,
to appease the myriad people,
he should not approach high grounds (=go hunting?),
he should not cook his food (=he should not eat cooked food, as in mourning),
he should not administer punishments but rewards,
he should not blame the people
or change his generals.
If the ruler was leading (the army) personally,
he must gather all the officials and tell them:
“You have all done your best,
it was not our fault,
but mine.”
My fight only has not been in harmony with Heaven’s will,
(now we should) go back to the army
and we will return to the fight.
He must summon the nobles and the outstanding officials of the state
to guide the soldiers and direct the army,
he should not return to the previous rules (of engagement).
In all cases the nobles should be positioned in the front positions of the first rows,
(if the are) in the back positions they will be destroyed (?).
For the ones advancing there should be salaries and enfeoffments according to the rules,
no crucial point is more befitting (than this).
Duke Zhuang asked again:
“Is there a way to go back (?) to the fight?”
He answered:
There is.
After the fight has started,
returning to the camp,
one gives commands in the middle of the army and says:
“Repair the armor and sharpen the weapons,
tomorrow we will fight again.”
The auxiliaries will roast (the food)
to soothe the ones who are reaching (back to) the ranks,
(as for the soldiers who) have lost their armored carts,
one should give them order not to go (back to) their ranks.
The next day, when the fight will begin,
they should be sent to the front ranks.
Their spies you should have them come and tell them:
“Their generals are all wounded,
their carriages and hand driven carts are all damaged,
telling them that they should move soon.
Then you should tell the untrained soldiers
to eat early
and to put the weapons on hand driven carts,
with everyone carrying his own food.”
After the fight has started,
you will measure (their merits),
making it so that they should not be negligent,
and that you will not let the people in doubt.
As for your turtles and milfoil (divinations),
in every case that must say that you will win.
You should change the cover of your drums,
and put order in your equipment.
The next day when they return to their ranks,
they will certainly go beyond the place (they occupied the day earlier= advance).
This is the way to go back (?) to the fight
Duke Zhuang asked again:
“Is there a way to return to (fight after) a prolonged battle?”
He answered:
“There is.
One must be cautious and restrained,
if it is like this how could one not win?
One should not be reckless and be enticed (by the enemy),
and (the army) will certainly go beyond the former assault (=advance).
One should reward the ones who grabbed (enemy’s heads),
and strengthen (=reassure) the timid,
to stimulate their resolution,
make happy the brave
and regretful the coward.
The myriad people would contribute their life,
and everyone would desire to win.
This is the way to return to (fight after) a prolonged battle.”
Duke Zhuang asked again:
“Is there a way to return to fight after a fierce battle?”
He answered:
“There is.
Collect (the dispersed soldiers) and (re)group them,
bind them together and treat them generously,
increasing the rewards and decreasing the punishments,
let (them) forget (the fear) of their death
and offer (them) their life,
let the good cart soldiers and foot soldiers go and get the bait (?),
let their resolution rise up,
make happy the brave,
make the timid regretful,
and then you will change the initial conditions.
This is the way to return to fight after a fierce battle.”
Duke Zhuang asked again:
“How to be good at attacking?”
He answered:
“The people have treasures,
called city walls,
strength,
and obstacles.
If these three are used to the utmost
and not abandoned,
the state and the main families are thereby aggrandized.
One good at attacking must use what one has
to attack what others do not have.
Duke Zhuang asked:
“How to be good at defending?”
When one’s food (reserves) are enough to feed (the people),
one’s weapons are enough to benefit them,
the strength of their city walls is enough to defend them,
between those above and those below there is harmony and earnestness,
one has entangled threads (=deep connections) with great states,
great states treat one with intimacy,
(no state) under Heaven can overcome (him).
As for soldiers, one wants them (rather) few and worthy,
when they are few they are easy to examine,
when success comes then they are easy to control,
if there is a victory,
one should personally lead the (handling of such) victory.
In employing people,
if it is not done personally then there is no diligence,
if there is no harmony there is no earnestness,
if there is no righteousness there is no submission.
Duke Zhuang said:
“How one does act to be close (to the people)?”
He answered:
“The ruler should not be afraid to toil himself (he should conduct personal observations),
to observe the true conditions (extant) between those above and those below;
the litigations of the common people and the widows.
the ruler should personally attend to their litigations
Even if there is imperfect knowledge,
as long as there is impartiality,
the people will feel close to him.
Duke Zhuang asked again:
“How one does act to be in harmony (with the people)?”
He answered:
“Do not be partial towards favorites,
do not coerce your elders,
make your rewards just and your adjudications correct,
then the people will feel in harmony with you.”
Duke Zhuang asked again:
“How one does act to be righteous (with the people)?”
He answered:
“One should rank (people) according to their (military) accomplishments and exhalt the worthy.
If somebody can rule one hundred people,
let him lead one hundred people,
if somebody can rule the army
let him be a general.
You should give (positions) to those having wisdom,
give them to those having ability,
then the people will consider you righteous.
Moreover I have heard this:
the soldier have a leader,
the army a general,
the state a ruler,
these three are the means to fight a war.
Therefore the ruler of the people does not begrudge feudal endowments,
does not control the army (imposing on his generals),
does not avoid (recognizing) mistakes,
and by these means comprehensively educates the state and the people.
Duke Zhuang said:
“Are these three things enough to make war?”
He answered:
“You must be careful.
In winning you cannot but be cautious.
If you are not thorough (in these three things),
you will not be lasting,
if you will not be harmonious
they will not be earnest,
if you will not be modest and fearful [...]
[...] their intent, will be few.
Duke Zhuang asked again:
“I have heard this saying:
once he proffered a word and the army is all reinvigorated,
once he proffered a word and the army all is ready to go,
are there such cases?”
He answered:
“There are.
To offer blood covenants (?) to the ghosts and spirits
and disregard the military
is not the way to educate the people,
the king should know this.
This is the way of the early kings.”
Duke Zhuang said:
“Mo, what I just said is not correct,
and I should not have been confused by the petty way (?).
(Now) I just want to hear about the place (=time) of the three dynasties.”
Cao Mo answered:
“I have heard this:
‘In the past the rise of the enlightened kings under Heaven,
in each case depended on their age
and on their person (=right time and right characteristics).
Modern and ancient times are very different,
so I do not dare to answer you by means of (the example of) ancient times.
But in antiquity there were also great methods,
(namely that) invariably who is reverent and moderate obtains it (=government)
and who is arrogant and excessive loses it.
And your majesty should also definitely listen to (the examples of) Yu, Tang, Jie and Zhou.
